ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: All about emerging technology trends, and easily understood ways to digest the economics behnid them.

- New econ models
- Discussions
- Industry overviews were helpful
- Extremely relevant

I gained knowledge of economic models that apply to new technology (searching costs, durable goods, two-part tariffs, dominant/fringe firms, vertical integration/separation, bundling, etc). I also learned about industry analysis and Porter's Five Forces.
I learned how technology is changing the way businesses work and make profits.
Learned quite a bit about the intersection of IP and Econ.
Application of microeconomics and how it applies to current day business models. Got some high level insight into general trends in AI / consumer tech.

I really learned a lot from this course, it is really going to help me professionally because you learn how to apply so many economic models to different problems. At some point in the course, we would get to a new problem and I could guess how we would go about solving it. We also learned how to do industry analyses and the impact of artificial intelligence on many of these problems

I mainly learned three things in this class. First, I learned more about the economics of innovation and the IP protection system (patents, copyrights, etc.). Second, I learned how we can analyze innovation and IP protection through economic, mathematical models. Finally, I learned how to do an industry analysis.

Economics of New Technologies means the economics of: near-monopolies, personalized pricing, market segmentation, price discrimination, copyrights & trademarks, durable goods, Porter's Five Forces industry analysis, price competition, searching costs, licensing, patent pools, network effects, recommender systems, mergers & acquisitions, vertical separation & integration, venture capital

This course applies some of the computational techniques learned in previous classes, but is largely about applying economic concepts to innovation. It was interesting to see how we may be able to model certain facets of businesses and innovation with economics, but this was not very vigorous.
I learned about how we can use economics to evaluate different models of innovation. I also learned about how to do an industry analysis
A theoretical approach to the effects of new tech and learned about a lot of cool new tech coming out
I learned more about economic models, especially those involving technology.
Economic concepts behind mergers and acquisitions, new technologies, integration. etc.
Solid microeconomics concepts and thorough understanding of market dynamics including price discrimination, patents, and innovation strategies.
I learned about economic models of new technology and conducted an industry analysis
I learned a lot about the economics of technology today which I found pretty useful given how much technology is being integrated into our daily lives
This course certainly touched on really important, relevant economic topics. And Professor Chalioti is amazing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: great instructor; very chill psets and exams; student presentations on industry analysis. Weaknesses: a bit too much math for my liking
Nothing! Eva's teaching style is incredible and office hours were so beyond helpful. thank you, Eva.

- Very relevant to real life
- Responsibility in projects
- Teamwork

Strengths: Eva is extremely kind and knowledgeable about the topic, and she is very organized with her lectures. The material is an appropriate amount of challenge: it's essentially intermediate micro concepts applied in interesting ways. And it was definitely interesting to have models for things like searching costs.

Weaknesses: None.
Strengths: professor is amazing and great teacher.

I loved this course! The course was very well-structured and the exams were extremely fair. Student presentations were also engaging, and the models felt applicable to the real world (good amount of game theory, situational optimization).

Strengths: Well structured lecture style senior seminar, very mathy (which I enjoyed), exams very fair (from problem sets)
Weaknesses: Nothing

Strengths: very reasonable homework and tests, pretty interesting lectures, office hours were very helpful, Prof Chalioti is great
Weaknesses: I thought that lectures could have been more engaging is Prof Chalioti let us discuss more. Would have helped keep everyone engaged

The course goes at a really nice pace, it was perfect for the way that I learned. There is a good number of problem sets and the office hours are always extremely helpful. The professor cares a lot and wants you to succeed. It's a really great senior seminar.

This course has many strengths. I loved that the class revolved around applying the somewhat abstract models we learned in intermediate micro to more tangible scenarios like incentivizing innovation and firm competition. We learned the practical skill of industry analysis: how to research and get an overview of an industry, the major players, impactful technologies, and future trends. The midterm and final exams were very fair, predictable, and based entirely on what we had done in class or homework. The workload was extremely reasonable. There was no busywork and I never felt stressed about or overwhelmed by this class. Also, Eva is a wonderful instructor whose excitement for the material is infectious. She tries to make class fun and is very understanding.
Extremely interesting lectures, very well-organized, and fair exams (what you see on the board/slides and what you do on the psets is what you get).

The course was about 2/3 content and 1/3 presentations. The content was interesting but at times felt a bit disjointed. Im glad we discussed Porters 5 Forces, but the industry analyses did not always have an appropriate topic to delve into these more. I liked the presentations and thought it was cool to go deeper into a topic, but I wish they had been more specific to peoples interests or past work. I thought all of the concepts were interesting and gave a really good introduction to how economics could be applied to companies, but do wish the material was more rigorous and mathematically complex to make it feel more like a senior level course.
Really nice Professor!  Liked doing the projects
I really enjoyed the course!
good teaching, high student engagement
Very well structured. Lectures were very interesting, psets were engaging, material covered was relevant and insightful.

I loved this class!! Eva is a gem and actually makes the information relevant by using real life examples of tech companies we use everyday. She is so kind and passionate about the material and tries to make it as approachable as possible

The strength is Eva is an amazing professor that makes the course so much better. A weakness may be that engagement during class is somewhat low (but this is somewhat due to the fact that Eva is very nice and students are lazy and the class was late in the day).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you are looking for a relatively low-stress class to fulfill a senior Econ requirement. Eva is lovely and provides a lot of help with the psets and exams, so it's really a pretty easy class. However, I would hesitate to recommend it if you are not an Econ major and/or if you are looking for something a bit more intellectually stimulating. Much of the material is essentially profit maximization, partial derivatives from intermediate micro, and I don't think I will retain much of the models we learned. The student presentations were very informative though!

ABSOLUTELY. take it. if you're interested in the future in ANY capacity, take this class. The world is changing around us, and this class gives you the tools to conceptualize that in the context of your own life.
Yes, extremely relevant and interesting models you learn!

Yes, I would highly recommend this course to another student. It's an excellent senior seminar taught by a great professor, and the material is interesting. Workload is reasonable (weekly psets + midterm + a presentation + final), especially if you go to office hours for pset help. Tests are always fair, as Eva makes clear what you have to study for.
Yes 100%
Absolutely yes. Really nice senior seminar and interesting content + not bad workload.

I highly recommend this senior seminar. Eva is a gem, and the way she goes about teaching her class is top notch. Her exams and problem sets are very fair. And you can expect to get a good grade as long as you put in some sort of effort.
Yes if you want an applied - micro sort of class with reasonable homework / tests
Absolutely. I truly don't think there is another econ senior seminar as good as this one. I truly will miss having professor chalioti next semester. If you can get in, you absolutely won't regret it.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The material we learn is fascinating and shows how we can apply the abstract models we learned in intermediate micro to more realistic scenarios like incentivizing innovation and firm competition. The midterm and final exams were very fair, predictable, and based entirely on what we had done in class or homework. The workload was extremely reasonable. There was no busywork and I never felt stressed about or overwhelmed by this class. Also, Eva is a wonderful instructor whose excitement for the material is infectious. She tries to make class fun and is very understanding.

Take it! Eva is the best. This was an awesome class. The assignments were 8 psets, 2 podcasts, an in-class midterm, a 7-min presentation on an industry of your choice, a 4-6 page write-up about that industry, and a final. In the first half the class, you learn about how technology has changed/impact the basic economic ideas you've learned in micro and macro. Like for monopolies--think about Google. Like for searching costs--think about online e-commerce. Like for vertical integration and price elasticity--think about Amazon. The second half of the class is about industry analysis. Using Porter's Five Forces framework, each student researches and presents on a topic and there are subsequent class discussions. I liked how presentations were on a wide range of industries:  blockchain, streaming, Amazon e-commerce, Tesla electric and autonomous cars, fintech, etc.

The professor, Professor Chalioti, is amazing and very kind. She definitely ensured this was a chill semester. I think you can learn a lot but just not very in-depth. Overall, the class was fun and engaging while not the most intellectually challenging. Id recommend it as a fun senior class.
Yes!  Good senior Econ seminar
Yes
Yes!
wonderful professor
Definitely yes. One of my favorite classes at Yale.
Absolutely! Take this even if you dont need an Econ Req. its really interesting to think about how tech is transforming our world
Yes, it was a great senior seminar and Professor Chalioti is an amazing professor
Yes, its great, especially for busy seniors.
